column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column4: and at Alderman Austin’s request
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By late July 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 537 feet of new 8-inch and 262 feet of new 12-inch  water main in W. 105th Place
column7: from S. Church Street to S. Vincennes Avenue and S. Vincennes  Avenue
column8: from W. 103rd Street to W. 107th Street. The old water main dates back to 1896
column9: and needs  to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column10: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column11: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column12: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column13: to the installation of new  pipes
column14: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column15: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column16: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column17: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column18: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column19: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column20: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column21: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  34th Ward Office: 773-928-6961  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main    When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column22: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column23: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column24: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column25: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column27: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column29: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column30: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column31: or if you would like your water  tested
column32: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column33: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column34: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column35: if you don’t already have one
column36: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column37: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely
